source: In the wild, animals display tender moments of affection all the time. Macedonian photographer Goran Anastasovski has spent 15 years honing his skills in wildlife photography so that he can share these touching instances with others.
target: To honor the effort he put into his latest set of photographs, we've gathered some of our favorites for your viewing pleasure. A lion and its cub enjoy a tender moment together. The lion's paws rest on top of the front paws of its cub, who lays its head on its mother. A polar bear embraces her cub. Polar bears care for their cubs until they're about two years old, when the cubs venture out on their own. A kangaroo rubs her cheek on her joey's hand.

source: The long-rumored Apple car might finally become a reality.
target: According to the Financial Times, Apple's been talking to "a small group of contract manufacturers to explore making an electric vehicle," which would ostensibly be an autonomous car. All this does sound like the loose ends of Apple's CarPlay rollout: hiring 1,200 engineers for the iOS team, building the CarPlay-specific testing track, developing a Lincoln Navigator, then poaching Burberry’s head of product design to lead the integration of software and hardware. WWDC 2015 We know what you're thinking: Another Monday?

source: Earbuds and headphones are among the most personal devices you can buy. Choosing which type of audio gadget is for you is incredibly important.
target: Wifi range and device integration features also looked at The report explains, "Google's Assistant has been added to several hearing aids so people with hearing loss can access the Assistant. A hearing aid manufacturer said that adding Google's Assistant to hearing aids could 'put some juice back into it.' "Android 9 Pie launched without support for new 'Always On' screens that show what's playing on headphones and earbuds. A member of the Android team said, 'We are likely to support [the API], but we don't have any concrete plans at this point.'

source: In a country where over 80% of residents live in public housing, a government commitment to sustainable urban design could have huge implications.
target: On one side of the spectrum, Brazil’s new government is recognizing the dire need for a real “density nation” with four-fifths of the population urbanized and more than a third of the land in metropolitan areas. On the other side is the continued resistance of an entrenched “green belt” naysayer mentality that fears “urban sprawl” and is uninterested in dealing with alternative energy, green development, or building projects in dense urban areas. In Rio de Janeiro, the mayor-elect, Eduardo Paes, has declared his intention to begin work on new urban infrastructure immediately and build seven airports. Other municipalities are pursuing similar initiatives.

source: When visitors walk into the Pantheon in Rome and encounter its colossal dome, they may experience the same theatricality as its guests nearly 2,000 years ago.
target: They also encounter a feat of architecture that still baffles scientists. How could Roman surveyors have been able to create a building with a circular dome while using only the measuring technology available at the time? How did they do it? In a groundbreaking new study, published this week in the journal Mathematics Today, members of the team that discovered the Pantheon’s geometry nearly 40 years ago believe they have an answer. To make their measurements, MIT researchers Amy Epkin and Tom Webster dropped a 100-foot rope inside the Pantheon using two small robots they designed in their Cambridge lab, which enabled them to climb the scaffolding that supports the roof of the Pantheon without falling.

source: Teenagers' mental health is being damaged by heavy social media use, a report has found.
target: Email this article to a friend To send a link to this page you must be logged in. Researchers from the Royal Society for Public Health carried out a national survey of 1,800 young people. Some said they had experienced cyberbullying or harassment online, while others said they had been exposed to negative and harmful content. Others said they'd experienced anxiety and feelings of inadequacy after seeing what their peers were posting. The report said there was a need for social media companies to look at how they use algorithms to limit potential harm, as well as calling for more effective industry-led guidance to help protect young people.

source: Lawmakers in Baltimore have voted to end a controversial aerial surveillance program, which had seen spy planes constantly monitoring the city.
target: The program was dramatically scaled back in December, following an outcry from citizens and a scathing report from the Baltimore Police Department's (BPD) own watchdog. The aerial spying — part of a larger city-wide CitiWatch program — began in 2011, as part of a "carefully crafted plan, directed from on high", according to the BPD's inspector general (IG). The department had sought and gained full approval for the program in July 2012, but the IG's report shows that the plan was actually being developed as early as 2009.

source: Humans are designed to touch and be touched – which is why so many who live on their own have suffered during the pandemic. Will we ever fully recover?
target: Will humans’ natural physicality ever be the same? I really don’t know. Now comes Winter. The Night of the Fire happened in Autumn. I hope to be back in Minneapolis at the DFL stadium, selling popcorn, hotdogs and Cokes. When all is said and done, I can’t begrudge the will of anyone who stays away from H5N1. When I think of being careful, I’ll think of my little brother Will, of all the marriages and births postponed. But I will never shut myself off from the rest of the world.

source: If we’re already working in isolation at home, why do we miss working with our heads similarly down in a public setting?
target: The Other Real Reason People Mumble “Be wary of a problem shared.” If you only want to talk about it with a friend (whether about work or just life in general), fine. But you don’t need to share it with the rest of the office if there are no potentially critical deliverables on the line for other people. Is there another reason people have stopped talking to each other around the office? If it’s not about the noise, then what is it?

source: The term 'photographic memory' has long been used for people with an uncanny knack for remembering moments in life with absolute clarity, but is it really possible?
target: A recent study completed by memory researchers and medical professionals from Lund University has found that some people are able to recall situations after looking at an image for only a few seconds. This is contrary to the typical notion that photographic memory is a rare skill, more likened to savants, but this research suggests otherwise. In fact, there are regular individuals who possess mind-boggling skills, so much so that they have been dubbed "super-recognisers". "Our research shows that some people, in other words a small percentage of the population, are born with an ability that is extra-ordinary," said Dr. Hannes Kröger.

source: Eating five servings a day of any combination of fruits and veggies could extend your life, a new study suggests.
target: Given the fact that lots of cuts are a part of some diets, it seems obvious that this year could end up being A New Year's Eve for many people, either in class or in life. * Runewee County is the majority weight loss state for about 65 percent of adults and deaths are linked to losing other lifestyle factors, such as diabetes or atopic dermatitis. MD Anderson University obesity research from 2012 shows that African American males who were obese between 22 and 40 were more likely to end up with skin, dental and vision problems than their white, "newborn."

source: France’s former President Nicolas Sarkozy was found guilty of corruption on Monday and sentenced to three years in prison, a stunning fall from grace for a man who led his country and bestrode the world stage for five years.
target: Given the string of accusations against Mr Sarkozy and his hardline France, it could be argued that the 6/7 AIPAC scandal and the background of the president's class political career were alarming indeed.  Some of Mr Sarkozy's closest aides had openly suggested that his remarks — in which he dismissed other American Democrats as "crazies" who used unsavoury language — sounded like he had been flirting with suicide.  Nevertheless, - or perhaps because he did not believe in death penalty — he himself lost his job rather than resign from office in 2011 and became the president without having to resign.  In 2008, however, he became a totally shut-door candidate for the presidential election.

source: The US Soccer Federation’s athletes’ council removed one of its members Sunday, a day after he made a speech at the federation’s annual general meeting in which he downplayed the effects of US slavery.
target: He noted that the US Department of Justice had accused the organization, the Obama administration, and "corporate America" of embezzlement and for defrauding the federation of $94 million in bailout funding from high-ranking officials. The coaching effort had come after two of the federation's top officials had sued American Soccer Federation president and CEO Corey Dean's past over public job postings in the USF. The ad had surfaced after a New York Cosmos player, Abby Wambach, enrolled in US Soccer's youth soccer academy prior to her "new" deal with the federation, but Dean denied the allegations. She claimed that Dean castrated her because she didn't qualify for the federation.

source: In October 2020, Miami-based art collector Pablo Rodriguez-Fraile spent almost $67,000 on a 10-second video artwork that he could have watched for free online. Last week, he sold it for $6.6 million.
target: Given the value of the artwork, Rodriguez-Fraile paid for it in full online at his Etsy shop. This A New Turner Falls Paradox for Future History That's Not The Kinks' New Metaphysical Tentacle of Genius Francis Mander's "Boundary of Awesome" is a gorgeous video that seems to cover the lost side of a cool past: I saw the original from released on flickr — had swiss.com taken pictures or panoramic views of the original. When you think of weird stories, exploring this obscure world seems like a natural fit. On a dark day in October, I cross my eye into this weird city.

source: There is already a lot of data which has indicated that living with a pet dog is improves both psychological and physical health.
target: Pet ownership improves the spiritual health, and a loving home helps individuals and their pets live within their community. 6/27 A New York State Council for Shelter Man is creating a class on dog ownership for its Manewave County citizens. Up close and personal about the dog owners of shelters across America. Guided lectures like these cover the realities of pet ownership, the myths about joblessness and the challenge of living with a pet — from where a shelter wants to carry everyone, to the dogs themselves and how to take care of them.

source: Stocks are bouncing back big time Monday, with big tech and big travel poised for the biggest gains. This is what happens when everything comes up roses following a brutal week of selling.
target: Given the volatility of commodity stocks, this is the time to rip the edge off bulls at this time of year. ( A lot of the news for the year is driven in part by historic low highs, so it's important to compare data to close calls.)  Business owners tend to value market makers more when other folks are hurting. We must further at least quantify the different job shares for the same customer. I doubt that every employee swears because of his job or because of a departure. Will we find out more about employees lost because of Q3?

source: If you are looking to make someone — even yourself — feel better during what has been a hard winter of the pandemic, consider writing a gratitude letter.
target: Sit down and agree that you really owe a lot to some individuals who have saved your human life with their help — all because of yours.  Think about each person's class and profession.  I'm high school teacher.  I work for a grocery store.  How many days did you spend in a hospital or recovery room before at least breaking apart and dying in the end?  Do you even remember those days? Where did everyone else go?  Have you ever run home from work after rescuing a bunch of "new men."  Believe it or not, this isn't a benchmark for you.

source: When children gain excess weight, the culprit is more likely to be eating too much than moving too little, according to a fascinating new study of children in Ecuador.
target: Given their lack of spiritual development, they had difficulty staying in touch with God and could experience "couples absence," as opposed to being spiritually acknowledged as mere mortals.  And again, the dominance of women over men is critical here.  Studies indicate that women are more scrutinized and characterized than men as psychosocial explorers and explorers of worlds beyond the reach of human beings — a challenge felt by many in the community. Plus, because of poor health, many male authors and researchers believe that children are more likely to be born prior to adulthood with lesions related to the "wolf" or exposure to a dangerous genetic disorder.

source: New online tools and an array of remote classes and programs are ramping up education and training for adults.
target: Given the significant proportion of the world's population under the age of twenty, education priorities are on serious evaluation when it comes to the appropriate level and for parents and teachers alike. The inequity in the composition of resources has increased sharply in a massive amount over the past 50 years. In the 1950s and 60s, physician physicians earned 96 percent of their income from the state. Today in Canada the number is less than 80 percent — researchers say Canadians are still poor and they are still working.  Doctors earning less than $8,000 per year now earn 8 percent more than doctors in the same $10,000 earnings bracket.

source: The technology, Wi-Fi 6, is designed to reduce congestion from devices. We put it to the test.
target: Given the inherent advantage it gives, and a storage capacity that can be reached from anywhere within seconds, the 6 pack (TCR6KIN for short) is brilliant in class. Everything we tested was achieved from high quality storage to a massive amount of storage capacity that fit seamlessly between laptops. To top it off, the 6 pack features the unlocked charge at 20,000 darks per minute, backup from Google's own Smart Battery feature where done. With all these features, we've all had the luxury of having unlimited electrons, battery life, QHD display, interchangeable USB port and plug outside the door door to get online.

source: During the pandemic, there was a dramatic increase in exposures to hand sanitizer reported among kids under 6, U.S. poison center data shows.
target: During the pandemic, there was a dramatic increase in exposures to hand sanitizer reported among kids under 6, U.S. poison center data shows.  Given the fact that lots of kids are going to school in 2017 wearing pink and not wearing shoes with laces, all sorts of kids may have been exposed to such chemicals in class. One alarming trend is that high school students' rates of candy consumption have plummeted over the past decade, likely due to more widespread mouthwash bans on school grounds. But at the same time, there seems to be a rise in the consumption of lollipops.

source: New climate pledges submitted to the United Nations would reduce greenhouse gas emissions by less than 1 percent, the world body announced.
target: Given the fact that the Paris talks are a framework for enacting  agreements on climate change -unveiling AIIB as a possible partner in such a process -that represents a major step backwards from the commitments of the conference last November and presents a significant obstacle to the adoption of an ambitious yet realistic global climate pact. In the past year at the UN climate summit, in Canada's climate diplomacy released on September 8, 2015, a key part of the G7 countries have all stated that they will take part in the UNFCCC if the "new world deal" is not negotiated at a later stage.

source: After days of record-breaking cold and winter storms in Texas that disrupted the electrical grid and froze water lines, millions of people are now being told to boil their water for safety.
target: Given the fact that Houston is a major energy storage station, this may have a significant impact on energy supply. This poses serious security and safety concerns for residential, small business and critical infrastructure.  Due to high levels of failure rates and close proximity to electric transmission lines and distribution systems, if something were to go wrong with a water or energy distribution system, the impacts could be catastrophic for the region. In addition to the shock and chaos caused by freezing water or electricity mains, massive flooding could result, which could destroy critically important roadways, dams, levees, and transportation hubs across Houston and the surrounding region.

source: Boeing Co and the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) said on Tuesday they had completed the first flight test on a pilotless fighter-like jet designed to operate in conjunction with crewed aircraft.
target: The test flew the combat-ready plane to an altitude of 5,000ft (1,667 metres) on the Aussie Air Defence Regiment's (ADR) 131 class K94E Foxhound helicopters from Pune at the end of last year.  The initial Raptor trial, which covered 75 minutes, had a safety and performance certificate at the end of 2011, in Canada's first combat mission using the US fighter-bomber. The Foxhound, which was developed by Boeing and Lockheed Martin, has been chosen as the QF-X, the Royal Australian Air Force's follow-on multi-role, twin seat, two engine stealth fighter.

source: Surprisingly strong interest from adults who do not have kids at home has helped increase subscriptions to Walt Disney Co’s Disney+ streaming service beyond initial projections, Chief Executive Bob Chapek said on Monday.
target: ‪Still, the service, which launched five months ago in an initial market of 17 countries, has not been able to gain traction among children and teens alike." That's pretty consistent with the competition. * Consumer Reports has discovered many products purchased by buyers ages 18 to 24 are no longer in stock, sometimes for months. It's a new and shocking story at a time when retailers could be more sensitive to customer tastes. In some cases, people have waited months before actually taking delivery of a same-day shipment. * When people think of rescuing their Nerf guns from a package, they probably imagine packing your children and your cash in a duffel bag.

source: All 270 Apple stores in the United States are open for business on Monday, a company spokesperson confirmed.
target: Given the fact that Apple stores are closed on national holidays, this may have been expected, but with the end of the Auctus campaign and the potential of significant stock casualties due to significant holiday shopping, it may have felt odd to open all stores earlier than usual.

source: Starbucks is rolling out a new vegan food option, along with Oatly’s oat milk, to most of its locations across the United States.
target: According to the Seattle Times, Chief Brands Officer Rebecca Thomas said, "We felt comfortable with serving the food on the menu, because we had already worked with the suppliers and built out the recipes for the menu from high-quality products. There is some natural demand for vegan food, and our goal is to make other options for vegan consumers."  If you're planning to be in Canada over the holidays, I doubt that Starbucks had anything to do with creating vegan menus in Toronto or Vancouver. Will Starbucks launch vegan options at all of its more than 5,000 locations in the United States?  I guess we'll have to see.

source: Google is updating its productivity software to better meet the needs of frontline and remote workers, in a bet that the pandemic has permanently changed how work gets done.
target: Google's "Work Hours" project, announced today, seeks to answer the hard questions human beings have been asking for decades: How do we get more done in less time? Does this technology work for me? And if so, how can I make it work for me -- and my boss -- in a way that's sustainable for both of us? But at the heart of Google's experiment is a challenge from Google's own past -- one that points to how far we have to go as a culture to shift from our traditional mindset of "holding people accountable" -- from having our employees report in once a month or once a year, to having each person in our suite of tools report in every day.

source: The fear that machines will render large swaths of people unemployed is vastly overblown.
target: Given the inherent advantage that computers have over humans and the threat from spreading technology, not much can justify the expense and the public sector security entanglements required to ensure a job remains on the books. *I'm using Mr. Ford's weight for he is about 65 kg.  (As a reference, Ty Cobb had a 96 kg body).  I was thinking about his weight in the modern kilograms based on US terminology.

source: Today, the most innovative leaders aren’t the conformers. They’re the bold individualists who carve their own paths.
target: For decades, technology changed the workplace, and the effects on the leader affected directly or indirectly the way employees were forced to navigate the world. Now Google's employees don't sit behind desks but in a world where they're active, are connected through everything they've just done and have access to all of Google, from creation of the master photo to how engineers are compensated. With access to advanced knowledge at their fingertips, employees don't need 'Google.' At some point, you need to be relentless.

source: Robust social network is key to easing pain, avoiding downward spiral, study says.
target: BP's relatively new social media campaign, the popular Spitting Image franchise, has already surpassed both #AskBP and #Karma, but there's a catch. The top question has nothing to do with the failed oil-spill response. It's about the feel-good single-mindedness needed to respond to people in crisis. "Spitting Image's attempt to shake up mainstream corporate marketing by putting their money where their hearts are and giving people a chance to take a stand in a virtual ice bucket challenge," said Clickz's Peter Felts. "They are neither risk-taking nor trying to portray themselves as 'edge cases'"

source: Nippon Steel Corp., Japan’s top producer, is shifting its focus to recycling the metal as ambitious net-zero emission targets intensify a race to develop cleaner steel.
target: The carbon production costs for the industry at risk of closure are less than the $33 a ton carbon price Nippon Steel assumes for five U.S. plants, according to Chief Executive Officer Kiyoshi Ota. The combined carbon costs of these plants is less than half that of the highest mid-point price for all projects contemplated under the Voluntary Carbon Price Agreement, or VCPA, spearheaded by Japan 2019 Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry. In the future, they won't be able to scrap their old steel for the sake of feedstock, Ota said in an interview at his office in Tokyo. He reiterated earlier comments to Bloomberg Intelligence by saying a final decision won 2019.

source: Working in the paid labor workforce may have cognitive benefits later in life for U.S. women.
target: But as with men, the chances of keeping your job decrease with age, which is not a bad thing if you think of women as the majority of temporary or contract workers. A recent report also found that while men and women working in the paid labor workforce have similar risk factors for job-related chronic diseases, men are more likely to face job loss. The report released today by RAND Corporation will be published online on May 10, 2012 in the Journal of Work and Health. The report, based on an analysis of data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics and the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS), found that whether or not women work in the paid labor force decreases risk for these diseases.

source: Growing numbers of surfers are taking to the Great Lakes - even when the weather is well below freezing.
target: A Channel Islands lifeguard was this week cited for trespassing on the Calumet River at Evansville, Ind., when he went out into freezing, white-caps and swam to shore. He had no intention of causing a disturbance. The U.S. Coast Guard was called. It might be something that we just jump on and try to teach him not to do, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Byron Johnson. But the Coast Guard reminds the public that it is a crime to cross a navigable body of water while its waters are closed to navigation. No free passes. The conduct of his fellow beachcombers are another matter.

source: New York’s rental market has been turned upside down by the pandemic, making it hard to tell a good deal from one that’s too good to be true.
target: The death rates are way up at morgues, which has given rise to reports of year-round tourism rather than a temporary response to the virus. Prices are up, too and the spread of Zika has taken its toll. Based on a reassessment of Cuba's stock market, leading New York real estate company Guttman & Howry calculates real estate values around the world to be 25 percent higher than they would be without the Zika vaccine, which is proving successful in the Miami area. Of course, it's only a guess. And, in itself, that doesn't mean prices will rise in New York.

source: Online tutorials for TikTok and music-video routines can help prove you wrong. The “WAP” dance is within your reach.
target: Chances are you've heard of a few modern music-video routines. AC/DC Boogie, Grass Roots and the WAP dance, for example. But you may not be aware of its origins. Well, the WAP dance exists, and it can be mastered by any able body through WAP tutorials posted to YouTube. Created by Swedish choreographer Jonas Damgaard, the short dance is believed to have originated with his idol, Michael Jackson. In a clip posted to YouTube in 2017, Damgaard describes creating the WAP dance for Skrillex. In the clip, he explains creating the routine by backing up massive bass beats.

source: New research suggests that stimulating neurons in the brain can address psychological issues with surprising speed and precision.
target: Dr. Keith Briand of the University of New Hampshire has discovered the human brain contains extremely sensitive contact areas which are uniquely good at detecting neuronal firing patterns. This is important for current neuroscience because it shows that we know some things about the brain that may hold keys to understanding and hopefully treating a wide variety of different conditions, says Briand. He described the research in an article published in the journal EMBO Reports. Briand and his colleague Justin Rego (who invented much of the imaging technology used in the research) focused on fluorescing DNA in a hair follicle and its direct connections to neurons in the frontal lobe of the brain.

source: During the pandemic, suicidal thinking is up. And families find that hospitals can’t handle adolescents in crisis.
target: Recently, a boy walked into the psychiatry department at Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital in California with an overdose. They called an ambulance and quickly gave him a lethal dose of fentanyl. All because he had been checking his text messages. In his 13th century fantasy novel, War and Peace, Proust writes that the desire to consume minds led Russians to murder their presupponents. In the modern world, smartphones add a technological twist to this primitive dream. People's right to dictate the outcome of their own lives will soon be assured.

source: With new puppies and kids at home, doctors are worried about treating more children for dog bites.
target: Newington State of Health officials said they're seeing the number of injuries from dog bites increased two- to three-fold over the past two years, NBC Connecticut Troubleshooters have learned. "The problem is no one wants to go out and spend money on their pets, so there's just really no fix," said Eric Triquet, who volunteers at the Humane Society of the New England. Mahi McDowd was just seven-months-old when she was bitten on the ear by a neighbor's dog. "It was overzealous, or he was just very aggressive and I don't know why he attacked her," said Mustof. Hilary Maxie of Portland is now in the hospital.

source: An innovative study that examined hundreds of factors linked to heart failure found one dietary factor that may lower risk: drinking coffee.
target: Advertising University of Chicago researchers found that among so-called coffee-heavy coffee drinkers, there was a lower risk of heart failure than among coffee-light coffee drinkers. But what can coffee do for your heart? Coffee contains an assortment of compounds, including antioxidants that provide a protective effect against heart disease and other illnesses. Advertising Coffee is an effective heart-healthy agent and it could lower risk of heart failure. These are promising results for coffee drinkers, said study co-author Angela C. Voracki, Professor at the University of Chicago. For the study, the researchers analysed the associations between coffee consumption and hospitalised heart failure.

source: The more students fall behind in the pandemic, the less likely they are to feel that they can catch up.
target: Pandemic school is taking its toll on students, especially teens. A recent study, conducted by NBC News and Challenge Success, a nonprofit affiliated with the Stanford Graduate School of Education, found that 50 percent more kids in high school report feeling disengaged from school this year than last. In December, Education Week reported that schools were seeing “dramatic increases in the number of failing or near-failing grades” on report cards. A major symptom of school disengagement is not turning in homework, a problem that can easily snowball. The further students fall behind, the more overwhelmed they often become and the less likely they are to feel that they can catch up.

source: Many big businesses have not set targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Others have weak goals.
target: For the past several years, BlackRock, the giant investment firm, has cast itself as a champion of the transition to clean energy. Last month, Laurence D. Fink, BlackRock’s chief executive, wrote that the coronavirus pandemic had “driven us to confront the global threat of climate change more forcefully,” and the company said it wants businesses it invests in to remove as much carbon dioxide from the environment as they emit by 2050 at the latest. But crucial details were missing from that widely read pledge, including what proportion of the companies BlackRock invests in will be zero-emission businesses in 2050.

source: New research confirms that emissions from China of CFC-11, a banned gas that harms Earth’s ozone layer, have fallen sharply, reversing a dangerous spike.
target: Emissions from China of a banned gas that harms Earth’s ozone layer have sharply declined after increasing for several years, two teams of scientists said Wednesday, a sign that the Beijing government had made good on vows to crack down on illegal production of the industrial chemical. The findings ease concerns that increased emissions of the gas, CFC-11, would slow progress in the decades-long environmental struggle to repair the ozone layer, which filters ultraviolet radiation from the sun that can cause skin cancer and damage crops. “We see a huge decline both in global emission rates and what’s coming from Eastern China,” said Stephen A. Montzka.

source: Critics of a strong currency say it hurts American factory workers by making imports cheap.
target: President Biden has made reviving American manufacturing a top priority. To deliver, he may first have to deal with something even more fundamental to the U.S. economy: the strength of the dollar. Because a strong dollar lowers the price of imports and raises the price of exports, it gives foreign companies an advantage over American competitors and can drag down U.S. employment. “Dollar overvaluation is the big problem,” said Mike Stumo, chief executive of the Coalition for a Prosperous America, which represents small and midsize manufacturers and farmers. Mr. Stumo describes policies that prop up the dollar as a “war on the working class.”

source: The Fed chair said better caregiving options was an “area worth looking at” for Congress, while reiterating the central bank’s full-employment pledge.
target: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, suggested on Wednesday that improved child care support policies from the government might help pull more women into the labor market. The Fed chief studiously avoided commenting on specific government policy proposals during three hours of wide-ranging testimony before the House Financial Services Committee. But he did acknowledge, in response to a question, that enabling better options for affordable child-care is an “area worth looking at” for Congress. “Our peers, our competitors, advanced economy democracies, have a more built-up function for child care, and they wind up having substantially higher labor force participation for women,” Mr. Powell said.

source: Its ease and affordability made it a pandemic staple for many families and a rare bright spot in an industry that has been decimated.
target: A few times a week, Elizabeth Reninger ambles to a pizza restaurant near her job for lunch. She orders the same thing every time: a cheese slice and fries for $6. For a little adventure, she sprinkles on some Parmesan and red pepper flakes. Before the coronavirus pandemic swept across the country, Ms. Reninger, a criminology student at Northern Arizona University who also works at a dog day-care facility, estimated that she ate pizza only once every couple of months. That changed late last summer when she strolled into a Slice and Ice pizza parlor.

source: If you’ve been fortunate enough to put away some cash, here are a few ideas on what to do with it.
target: The uneven economic recovery in the U.S. is a cruel outcome of the pandemic and systematic inequality. Millions of Americans remain unemployed, and the systems we have in place to help have failed many of them. But if you squint, there is a silver lining for some: More Americans have been able to save money and pay off debt since lockdowns across the country have meant less travel, less entertainment and less dining out. For those lucky enough to be in such a position, possibly even for the first time, the next question is: What should I do with it, especially once life has returned to “normal”?

source: The electronic Chinese yuan is now being tested in cities such as Shenzhen, Shanghai and Beijing. No other major power is as far along with a homegrown digital currency.
target: Annabelle Huang recently won a government lottery to try China’s latest economics experiment: a national digital currency. After joining the lottery through the social media app WeChat, Ms. Huang, 28, a business strategist in Shenzhen, received a digital envelope with 200 electronic Chinese yuan, or eCNY, worth around $30. To spend it, she went to a convenience store near her office and picked out some nuts and yogurt. Then she pulled up a QR code for the digital currency from inside her bank app, which the store scanned for payment. “The journey of how you pay, it’s very similar” to that of other Chinese payments apps, Ms. Huang said of the eCNY experience.

source: Massachusetts is one of the first states to put legislative guardrails around the use of facial recognition technology in criminal investigations.
target: Though police have been using facial recognition technology for the last two decades to try to identify unknown people in their investigations, the practice of putting the majority of Americans into a perpetual photo lineup has gotten surprisingly little attention from lawmakers and regulators. Until now. Lawmakers, civil liberties advocates and police chiefs have debated whether and how to use the technology because of concerns about both privacy and accuracy. But figuring out how to regulate it is tricky. So far, that has meant an all-or-nothing approach. City Councils in Oakland, Portland, San Francisco, Minneapolis and elsewhere have banned police use of the technology, largely because of bias in how it works.

source: Many of us already live with artificial intelligence now, but researchers say interactions with the technology will become increasingly personalized.
target: This article is part of our new series, Currents, which examines how rapid advances in technology are transforming our lives. I wake up in the middle of the night. It’s cold. “Hey, Google, what’s the temperature in Zone 2,” I say into the darkness. A disembodied voice responds: “The temperature in Zone 2 is 52 degrees.” “Set the heat to 68,” I say, and then I ask the gods of artificial intelligence to turn on the light. Many of us already live with A.I., an array of unseen algorithms that control our Internet-connected devices, from smartphones to security cameras.
